# The `Constants.h` File Reference

<DoxygenPage pluginConfig={pluginConfig}>

This file contains the declarations for the subclasses of Constant, which represent the different flavors of constant values that live in LLVM. <a href="#details">More...</a>

## Description {#details}

This file contains the declarations for the subclasses of Constant, which represent the different flavors of constant values that live in LLVM.

Note that Constants are immutable (once created they never change) and are fully shared by structural equivalence. This means that two structurally equivalent constants will always have the same address. Constants are created on demand as needed and never deleted: thus clients don&#39;t have to worry about the lifetime of the objects.

<Link id="l00290" /><CodeLine lineNumber="290"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// This returns a ConstantFP, or a vector containing a splat of a ConstantFP,</Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00294" /><CodeLine lineNumber="294"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">static</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/constantfp/#a5bd16c2fbe755cda66b18d56761038ea">Constant</a> &#42;get(<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/type">Type</a> &#42;Ty, </Highlight><Highlight kind="keywordtype">double</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> V);</Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00329" /><CodeLine lineNumber="329"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// We don&#39;t rely on operator== working on double values, as it returns true</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00330" /><CodeLine lineNumber="330"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// for things that are clearly not equal, like 0 and 0.0.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00331" /><CodeLine lineNumber="331"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// As such, this method can be used to do an exact bit-for-bit comparison of</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00332" /><CodeLine lineNumber="332"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// two floating point values.  The version with a double operand is retained</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00333" /><CodeLine lineNumber="333"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// because it&#39;s so convenient to write isExactlyValue(2.0), but please use</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00334" /><CodeLine lineNumber="334"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// it only for simple constants.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00390" /><CodeLine lineNumber="390"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00391" /><CodeLine lineNumber="391"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Base class for aggregate constants (with operands).</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00392" /><CodeLine lineNumber="392"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00393" /><CodeLine lineNumber="393"><Highlight kind="comment">/// These constants are aggregates of other constants, which are stored as</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00394" /><CodeLine lineNumber="394"><Highlight kind="comment">/// operands.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00395" /><CodeLine lineNumber="395"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00396" /><CodeLine lineNumber="396"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Subclasses are \\a ConstantStruct, \\a ConstantArray, and \\a</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00397" /><CodeLine lineNumber="397"><Highlight kind="comment">/// ConstantVector.</Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00579" /><CodeLine lineNumber="579"><Highlight kind="comment">/// ConstantDataSequential - A vector or array constant whose element type is a</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00580" /><CodeLine lineNumber="580"><Highlight kind="comment">/// simple 1/2/4/8-byte integer or half/bfloat/float/double, and whose elements</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00581" /><CodeLine lineNumber="581"><Highlight kind="comment">/// are just simple data values (i.e. ConstantInt/ConstantFP).  This Constant</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00582" /><CodeLine lineNumber="582"><Highlight kind="comment">/// node has no operands because it stores all of the elements of the constant</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00583" /><CodeLine lineNumber="583"><Highlight kind="comment">/// as densely packed data, instead of as Value&#42;&#39;s.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00584" /><CodeLine lineNumber="584"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00585" /><CodeLine lineNumber="585"><Highlight kind="comment">/// This is the common base class of ConstantDataArray and ConstantDataVector.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00586" /><CodeLine lineNumber="586"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00587" /><CodeLine lineNumber="587" lineLink="/docs/api/classes/llvm/constantdatasequential"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">class </Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"><a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/constantdatasequential/#affe367e75e60cf8dfdb8f501d15eff91">ConstantDataSequential</a> : </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">public</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/constantdata/#ade3ec5a4a86ffd069698509c87b6a604">ConstantData</a> &#123;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00588" /><CodeLine lineNumber="588" lineLink="/docs/api/classes/llvm/constantdatasequential/#aa81f87de855d80e4275071841a7e0c83"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">friend</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">class </Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"><a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/constantdatasequential/#aa81f87de855d80e4275071841a7e0c83">LLVMContextImpl</a>;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00589" /><CodeLine lineNumber="589" lineLink="/docs/api/classes/llvm/constantdatasequential/#a5bd16c2fbe755cda66b18d56761038ea"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">friend</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">class </Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"><a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/constantdatasequential/#a5bd16c2fbe755cda66b18d56761038ea">Constant</a>;</Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00593" /><CodeLine lineNumber="593"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> </Highlight><Highlight kind="keywordtype">char</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> &#42;DataElements;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00594" /><CodeLine lineNumber="594"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00595" /><CodeLine lineNumber="595"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// This forms a link list of ConstantDataSequential nodes that have</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00596" /><CodeLine lineNumber="596"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// the same value but different type.  For example, 0,0,0,1 could be a 4</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00597" /><CodeLine lineNumber="597"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// element array of i8, or a 1-element array of i32.  They&#39;ll both end up in</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00598" /><CodeLine lineNumber="598"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// the same StringMap bucket, linked up.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00599" /><CodeLine lineNumber="599"><Highlight kind="normal">  std::unique&#95;ptr&lt;ConstantDataSequential&gt; Next;</Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00691" /><CodeLine lineNumber="691"><Highlight kind="comment">/// An array constant whose element type is a simple 1/2/4/8-byte integer or</Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00695" /><CodeLine lineNumber="695"><Highlight kind="comment">/// of as Value&#42;&#39;s.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00816" /><CodeLine lineNumber="816"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Return a ConstantVector with the specified constant in each element.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00817" /><CodeLine lineNumber="817"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// The specified constant has to be a of a compatible type (i8/i16/</Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l01191" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1191"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Return the identity constant for a binary opcode.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01192" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1192"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// If the binop is not commutative, callers can acquire the operand 1</Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l01194" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1194"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// shift has a zero identity constant for operand 1: X shift 0 = X. If this</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01195" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1195"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// is a fadd/fsub operation and we don&#39;t care about signed zeros, then</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01196" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1196"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// setting NSZ to true returns the identity 0 instead of -0.0. Return</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01197" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1197"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// nullptr if the operator does not have an identity constant.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l01402" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1402"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//===----------------------------------------------------------------------===//</Highlight><Highlight kind="comment"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01403" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1403"><Highlight kind="comment">/// &#39;undef&#39; values are things that do not have specified contents.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01404" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1404"><Highlight kind="comment">/// These are used for a variety of purposes, including global variable</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01405" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1405"><Highlight kind="comment">/// initializers and operands to instructions.  &#39;undef&#39; values can occur with</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01406" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1406"><Highlight kind="comment">/// any first-class type.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01407" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1407"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01408" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1408"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Undef values aren&#39;t exactly constants; if they have multiple uses, they</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01409" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1409"><Highlight kind="comment">/// can appear to have different bit patterns at each use. See</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01410" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1410"><Highlight kind="comment">/// LangRef.html#undefvalues for details.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01411" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1411"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
